--- ATTACHMENT CONTENT ---
Formal Public Comment on OPM -2025-0004  
Docket ID:  OPM-2025-0004  
Title: Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service  
To Whom It May Concern:  
I write to strongly oppose the proposed regulation titled Improving Performance, 
Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service  (Docket ID: OPM –2025–0004). This 
regulation, which seeks to establish a new "Schedule Policy/Career" classification within 
the excepted service, is a direct threat to the integrity, independence, and democratic 
foundation of the U.S. civil service.  
This proposal is not a minor administrative adjustment; it is a sweeping and dangerous 
transformation of how federal personnel are hired, retained, and dismissed. Below are five 
critical reasons why this rule must be withdrawn.  
1. Erosion of Due Process and Merit Protections  
The proposed regulation, which would create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” 
classification within the excepted service, directly contradicts the foundational principles 
of a merit -based civil service. It would allow thousands of career federal employee s, those 
labeled as “policy -influencing” , to be stripped of the rights and protections afforded under 
Title 5 of the U.S. Code. These individuals could be terminated without cause, without 
notice, and without recourse , removing the procedural safeguards that ha ve long protected 
the integrity of our nonpartisan civil service.  
This is fundamentally at odds with the stated intentions of Executive Order titled Restoring 
Equality of Opportunity and Meritocracy  (April 2025). That EO opens with a powerful 
affirmation:  
“A bedrock principle of the United States is that all citizens are treated equally under 
the law... It encourages meritocracy... not favoritism.” (Sec. 1)  
Further, it underscores the importance of evaluating individuals based on “individual 
strengths, effort, or achievement” and explicitly warns against systems that undermine 
opportunities for individuals to succeed on their own merits:  
“Disparate -impact liability... has hindered businesses from making hiring and other 
employment decisions based on merit and skill...” (Sec. 1)  
Yet this proposed rule moves in the opposite direction. It does not encourage meritocracy, 
but instead replaces it with political discretion. It does not promote equal opportunity, but 
instead allows for arbitrary dismissal based on a shifting and opaque d efinition of “policy 
influence.” This directly undermines the very goal of treating individuals based on “their 
strengths, effort, or achievement.”  
If the administration is sincere in its belief that:  
“Employers should be able to use bona fide job -oriented evaluations when 
recruiting,”  — Section 1, Purpose  
then it cannot support a system in which qualified, experienced, and competent civil 
servants are denied job security , not because of performance or misconduct, but because 
they occupy roles that may be politically inconvenient . 
If the administration is committed to promoting individual merit, equal treatment under the 
law, and protection from arbitrary decision -making, then this proposed rule is an 
undeniable contradiction. The “Schedule Policy/Career” rule removes employment 
protections from qualified, experienced, and loyal civil servants, many of whom have 
dedicated their careers to upholding the law, regardless of political party.  
Rather than advancing meritocracy, this rule promotes ideological conformity by allowing 
for the removal of employees based on perceived political misalignment , turning a system 
grounded in qualifications and expertise into one vulnerable to favoritism and political 
coercion.  
Moreover, the rule would expose many employees to termination simply because they hold 
policy-related responsibilities , not because of poor performance, lack of merit, or legal 
misconduct, but because of where their role sits within an organizational chart.  
The President’s own Executive Order recognizes:  
“Citizens will be treated equally before the law and as individuals, not consigned to 
a certain fate based on their immutable characteristics.” (Sec. 1)  
Yet this regulation, by categorizing certain roles as inherently subject to political will, 
effectively consigns public servants to professional instability and career vulnerability —not 
based on individual merit or misconduct, but based on administrative d esignation and 
perceived policy influence.  
At its core, this rule trades merit for loyalty, skill for silence, and due process for political 
control. It is incompatible with the values enshrined in the American civil service system as 
a whole.  
This is not meritocracy.  
This is not due process.  
And this is not equality under the law.  
The Office of Personnel Management should uphold the merit system principles codified in 
law and reaffirmed by executive action. I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule in its 
entirety.  
2. Politicization of the Civil Service  
The proposed regulation grants the President unprecedented authority to unilaterally 
reclassify a wide range of federal positions into a new category  called “Schedule 
Policy/Career”  and effectively stripping those roles of the statutory protections that ensure 
a nonpartisan, merit -based federal workforce. This move would mark a radical shift in the 
civil service system by enabling the wholesale replacement of experienced professionals 
based not on performance or legal violations, but on perceived political alignment.  
This fundamentally politicizes the federal workforce, blurring the essential distinction 
between career civil servants , who are charged with implementing the law faithfully , and 
political appointees, who serve at the pleasure of the President.  
This regulation directly undermines several pillars of U.S. law:  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 2301 – Merit System Principles  
The federal merit system is governed by nine core principles, including:  
1. “Recruitment should be from qualified individuals from appropriate sources in an 
endeavor to achieve a workforce from all segments of society.  
2. “Selection and advancement should be determined solely on the basis of relative 
ability, knowledge, and skills after fair and open competition."  
3. “Employees should be protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or 
coercion for partisan political purposes.”  
Reclassifying policy -influencing roles into an at -will category contradicts every one of these 
principles by removing fair competition, merit -based selection, and protection from 
political coercion.  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 2302 – Prohibited Personnel Practices  
This law explicitly prohibits:  
• “Any personnel action based on political affiliation or conduct.”  
• “Any action that violates merit system principles.”  
Under this rule, civil servants in roles like policy analysis, grant oversight, and scientific 
evaluation could be terminated or reassigned solely because their professional 
recommendations differ from the political objectives of the current administration . This is 
the very type of action Congress sought to prevent when it codified protections against 
political abuse in the civil service.  
Public trust in federal agencies depends on their independence, professionalism, and 
consistency across administrations. This regulation opens the door to loyalty tests, where 
continued employment depends on agreement with political priorities , not legal obligation, 
scientific evidence, or expert judgment. That would:  
• Chill dissent and innovation  
• Deter qualified professionals from public service  
• Concentrate power in the Executive  
• Replace institutional expertise with ideological conformity  
In practice, this means public affairs officers could be fired for not echoing political talking 
points, scientists removed for reporting inconvenient findings, or regulatory experts purged 
for upholding laws the administration seeks to weaken.  
By eroding this firewall between policy implementation and political will, the proposed rule 
ignores the delicate constitutional balance between administration of the law and political 
leadership. This sets a precedent where federal employment is contingen t not on expertise 
or lawfulness, but on political loyalty , an arrangement more characteristic of authoritarian 
regimes than democratic societies.  
In a constitutional republic, the law , not the preferences of the President , must guide 
agency action. The civil service exists precisely to ensure continuity, competence, and 
accountability across changing political leadership.  
This rule would instead bring us one step closer to a patronage system that the Pendleton 
Act of 1883 , and every merit -based reform since  has sought to eliminate.  
By granting the President sweeping authority to reclassify roles into this new category, the 
regulation politicizes positions that are meant to remain nonpartisan. From regulatory 
analysts and grant administrators to public affairs officers and scientists,  a wide range of 
professionals could be targeted for their beliefs or actions  undermining the essential 
independence of federal agencies.  
This concentration of power in the executive branch is incompatible with democratic 
principles and opens the door to loyalty tests, purges, and the erosion of public trust in 
government.  
This proposed rule is not a technical reclassification ; it is a fundamental restructuring of 
the civil service that threatens the nonpartisan foundation of our federal government. It 
directly contradicts the core merit principles codified in federal law and undermines the 
very goals set forth in the April 2025 Executive Order on Restoring Equality of Opportunity 
and Meritocracy , which promotes individual merit, constitutional adherence, and equal 
treatment under the law.  
Instead of advancing those principles, this rule invites political interference, weakens legal 
safeguards, and destabilizes the institutions designed to serve the American people with 
impartiality and integrity.  
For the sake of our democracy, our public institutions, and our Constitution, I urge the 
Office of Personnel Management to rescind this rule in its entirety. At a minimum, 
substantial revisions must be made to:  
• Reinstate full due process protections for all reclassified employees  
• Limit the scope of reclassification to true political appointees  
• Ensure compliance with Title 5 merit system principles and prohibited personnel 
practices  
• Include explicit language protecting civil servants from political retaliation  
Anything less risks transforming our civil service into a tool of political enforcement . 
3. Threat to Whistleblowers and Good Governance  
One of the most alarming implications of the proposed “Schedule Policy/Career” 
classification is its potential to erode critical whistleblower protections, undermining 
ethical oversight and insulating the executive branch from lawful accountability.  
Under the Whistleblower Protection Act of 1989 (WPA), codified in 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8), 
federal employees are protected from retaliation when they disclose evidence of:  
• A violation of law, rule, or regulation,  
• Gross mismanagement,  
• Gross waste of funds,  
• An abuse of authority,  
• Or a substantial and specific danger to public health or safety.  
However, these protections explicitly exclude employees in “confidential, policy -
determining, policymaking, or policy -advocating positions” , a category that directly 
overlaps with the proposed definition of “Schedule Policy/Career” roles.  
By reclassifying large swaths of the federal workforc e, especially those engaged in 
regulatory, scientific, and policy oversight , this regulation could render thousands of civil 
servants ineligible for whistleblower protection. This would not only silence those best 
positioned to identify misconduct or illegality but also send a chilling message throughout 
the entire federal workforce: Speak up, and you may be punished without recourse.  
The proposed rule would functionally undermine several critical components of the federal 
accountability system:  
1. 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(9) – Retaliation Protections  
This statute protects employees who exercise appeal rights, cooperate with investigations, 
or refuse to obey orders that would require them to break the law. Those protections could 
be bypassed if agencies can simply reclassify employees as at -will.  
2.  Inspector General Act of 1978  
Federal Inspectors General (IGs) rely on the willingness of employees to report misconduct 
without fear of reprisal. Removing these protections discourages cooperation and weakens 
the independence of the IG system.  
3.  Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB)  
The MSPB is tasked with hearing appeals from employees who claim they’ve been subject 
to unlawful retaliation. If “Schedule Policy/Career” employees are stripped of MSPB 
access, there is no impartial forum to adjudicate whistleblower claims.  
The federal government depends on courageous, principled civil servants to report when 
policies are being broken, funds are being misused, or the public interest is being betrayed. 
These individuals have exposed:  
• Corruption in federal contracts  
• Unsafe practices in public health  
• Suppression of scientific data  
• Discrimination and abuse within agencies  
Silencing those voices does not promote efficiency —it protects misconduct.  By weakening 
whistleblower protections through broad reclassification, this rule:  
• Makes fraud, waste, and abuse harder to detect  
• Discourages good -faith reporting of legal violations  
• Creates a culture of fear, secrecy, and blind loyalty  
• Undermines the American public’s right to honest government  
In a healthy democracy, government accountability begins with those on the inside willing 
to speak truth to power. The proposed rule endangers that principle by removing key 
protections for those most likely to encounter wrongdoing. It rewards silence and punishes 
integrity, turning a system designed to serve the people into one that protects power at all 
costs.  
This is not good governance ; it is a recipe for unchecked executive abuse. I urge the Office 
of Personnel Management to withdraw or amend this rule to explicitly preserve 
whistleblower protections for all civil servants, regardless of their role in shaping or 
communicating policy.  
4. Undermining Checks and Balances  
The proposed rule not only dismantles protections for civil servants but also alters the 
balance of power between the branches of government, weakening core institutions 
designed to enforce lawful governance and prevent abuse. By granting the Executive 
Branch broad authority to unilaterally reclassify federal roles into “Schedule Policy/Career ,” 
the regulation effectively bypasses Congress, undermines existing statutory frameworks, 
and eliminates essential institutional safeguards. This action centralizes power in the 
hands of the President in a way that is inconsistent with the constitutional principle of 
separation of powers.  
This regulation directly undermines several pillars of U.S. law  and the Constitution : 
U.S. Constitution – Article I, Section 8  
Congress holds the power to “make all Laws which shall be necessary and proper for 
carrying into Execution the foregoing Powers.” That includes authority over civil service 
structures, personnel rules, and the administrative framework of federal agencies. By 
overriding long -standing statutory frameworks through regulatory action alone, the 
Executive is unilaterally reshaping a system Congress established and maintains.  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 1204 – Powers and Functions of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB)  
The MSPB is an independent agency tasked with ensuring merit system principles are 
upheld, adjudicating appeals of personnel actions, and protecting against prohibited 
personnel practices. The proposed rule strips thousands of employees of access to MSPB 
appeals, effectively defanging the agency and bypassing the enforcement mechanisms 
Congress created.  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 7521 – Protections for Administrative Law Judges (ALJs)  
Administrative judges  who oversee regulatory, enforcement, and benefits hearings across 
the federal government  are insulated from removal except for “good cause” as determined 
by the MSPB. The proposed rule could place these judges under Schedule Policy/Career, 
allowing their termination without cause or independent review, thus violating statutory 
protections and threatening the impartiality of legal proceedings across agencies.  
Independent administrative bodies like the Merit Systems Protection Board, the Office of 
Special Counsel, and agency -level adjudicative offices serve as vital bulwarks against 
political interference. They exist to ensure:  
• That personnel decisions are made lawfully,  
• That whistleblower protections are enforced,  
• And that citizens receive impartial decisions in disputes involving government 
benefits, enforcement, and regulation.  
The proposed rule threatens all of this by granting the President unchecked authority over 
appointments and terminations in roles critical to checks and balances, rule of law, and 
citizen recourse.  
The danger of executive overreach in federal employment has been well understood since 
the passage of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which abolished the 
patronage “spoils system.” Congress enacted these reforms after it became clear that 
allowing elected officials to fire and hire federal employees for political reasons eroded 
public trust and opened the door to corruption.  
This rule is a step back toward that dangerous model. It transforms roles that should be 
neutral, professional, and governed by law into positions that serve at the pleasure of a 
political leader , exposing our administrative institutions to manipulation, intimidation, and 
instability.  
The result would be an Executive Branch that not only administers policy but also controls 
all institutional resistance to unlawful conduct, a scenario the framers of our Constitution 
explicitly sought to avoid.  
In our constitutional system, no branch of government should be able to exercise 
unchecked power, particularly over the mechanisms of enforcement, oversight, and 
adjudication. The proposed rule undermines these checks and balances by concentrating 
personnel contr ol in the Executive and disabling independent bodies meant to constrain it.  
If enacted, this rule would not only jeopardize the integrity of the civil service but also erode 
the constitutional structure that protects individual rights and democratic governance.  
I urge OPM to withdraw or significantly amend this rule to ensure alignment with the 
Constitution, federal statutes, and the principles of independent, impartial public service.  
5. A Step Toward Authoritarianism  
The creation of the “Schedule Policy/Career” classification is not merely a bureaucratic 
adjustment ; it is a structural shift in governance that would bring the United States 
alarmingly close to the systems of control found in authoritarian regimes. By enabling the 
President to unilaterally reclassify and dismiss career federal employees who engage in 
policy, regulatory, or communications work, this rule dismantles one of the last remaining 
bulwarks against executive overreach: a nonpartisan, professional c ivil service.  
In a healthy constitutional democracy, federal employees are expected to serve the public, 
uphold the law, and execute the policies of the elected government without regard to party, 
ideology, or personality. The civil service is structured to ensure that public administration 
is guided by:  
• Professional expertise  
• Continuity across administrations  
• Fidelity to laws passed by Congress  
This proposal threatens to replace that professionalism with loyalty tests, where 
employment is contingent not on competence or compliance with law —but on personal 
allegiance to a President or administration.  
History offers chilling reminders of where this leads. Regimes that elevate personal loyalty 
above lawful governance inevitably breed corruption, suppress dissent, and erode the 
rights of citizens. What begins as administrative restructuring quickly become s a tool of 
political purification , and the consequences for democracy are profound.  
Before the Pendleton Act of 1883, federal jobs were awarded based on political patronage. 
Presidents routinely purged civil servants to make room for loyalists, ensuring that 
government agencies became extensions of partisan machinery. The result was insta bility, 
corruption, and a public administration that served power , not people.  
The Pendleton Act and later reforms were not accidental ; they were deliberate safeguards 
against autocracy. Repealing those protections in the form of this proposed rule does not 
merely revert us to a less efficient system. It dismantles over a century of hard -won reforms 
designed to protect democracy itself.  
This rule undermines the constitutional principle of checks and balances, concentrates 
undue power in the Executive Branch, and enables the systematic removal of individuals 
who may resist illegal or unethical orders.  
It also directly contradicts principles articulated in landmark rulings and documents, such 
as: 
Federalist No. 51: “Ambition must be made to counteract ambition.” The founders 
understood the need for internal restraints within government to preserve liberty.  
Myers v. United States (1926) and Humphrey’s Executor v. United States (1935): 
These cases drew lines around the President’s removal powers, affirming limits in 
contexts where independence is essential.  
The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978: This law reaffirmed Congress’s intent to 
protect employees from arbitrary political retaliation and to ensure a career 
workforce that could serve any administration impartially.  
Once politicized, the federal workforce becomes a tool not of democratic administration, 
but of personal rule. This regulation could:  
• Be used to silence dissenting internal voices  
• Enable mass firings based on ideology  
• Lead to the collapse of public confidence in government agencies  
• Empower future presidents to govern without oversight  
What results is a government that serves the President , not the people, and that structure 
is no longer a republic in any meaningful sense.  
The United States was never meant to be ruled by a king. Our founders fought a revolution 
to reject unchecked executive power. This regulation moves us closer to the very system 
they sought to replace.  
If the civil service can be purged at will, based on vague and sweeping criteria, then the 
institutions meant to preserve democracy become weapons to destroy it.  
We must not allow that to happen. The proposed rule must be withdrawn completely or 
radically revised to prevent its abuse by any present or future administration.  
Conclusion and Call to Action  
This regulation is incompatible with the laws, principles, and values that define the U.S. 
government. It erodes merit, eliminates accountability, and opens the federal workforce to 
political exploitation.  
I urge the Office of Personnel Management to rescind this rule in its entirety. If any 
elements are retained, they must be significantly amended to:  
• Preserve full due process and appeal rights;  
• Protect whistleblowers and independent adjudicators;  
• Reinforce merit -based hiring and promotion;  
• Prevent political retaliation;  
• Uphold statutory checks and constitutional balances.  
Withdraw this rule. Protect our civil service. Preserve our democracy.  
Respectfully,  
Free State Coalition
